sourceDesc:
<<<<<<< HEAD
The sermon preached at the Crosse, Feb. xiiii. 1607. By W. Crashawe, Batchelour of Diuinitie, and preacher at the temple; iustified by the authour, both against Papist, and Brownist, to be the truth: wherein, this point is principally intended; that the religion of Rome, as now it stands established, is still as bad as euer it was Crashaw, William, 1572-1626.
[16], 173, [1] p.
By H. L[ownes] for Mathew Lownes: and are to be solde at his shop in Paules Church yard, at the signe of the Bishops head, Imprinted at London : 1609.
Printer's name from STC. Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
=======
The sermon preached at the Crosse, Feb. xiiii. 1607. By W. Crashawe, Batchelour of Diuinitie, and preacher at the temple; iustified by the authour, both against Papist, and Brownist, to be the truth: wherein, this point is principally intended; that the religion of Rome, as now it stands established, is still as bad as euer it was Crashaw, William, 1572-1626.
[16], 173, [1] p.
By H. L[ownes] for Mathew Lownes: and are to be solde at his shop in Paules Church yard, at the signe of the Bishops head, Imprinted at London : 1609.
